text:
Hi!
I have a question regarding the usage of Automa.jl (but not with regards to biology). Is this the right place to ask?

text: Yeah, probably. <@U7HAYKY9X> is the most active Automa guru. I'm an apprentice automa-ton

text:
Is it possible / feasible to use Automa to do line by line parsing?

I have a file like this: <https://github.com/SebastianM-C/EPOCHInput.jl/blob/master/test/gauss/input.deck>
and I built a parser manually, but it's slow and buggy. I was wondering if it would be a better idea to switch to Automa

elements.text:
Is it possible / feasible to use Automa to do line by line parsing?

I have a file like this:
and I built a parser manually, but it's slow and buggy. I was wondering if it would be a better idea to switch to Automa

text: I'm asking about line by line parsing since I'm not sure if doing it at the byte level is that human readable / understandable in this case

elements.text: I'm asking about line by line parsing since I'm not sure if doing it at the byte level is that human readable / understandable in this case

text:
Are you saying do it by just defining an FSM on a per-line basis? I think you _could_, but I doubt it would be any better than julia's native string handling.

But you could define a machine that just gives you back blocks that you can deal with in pieces, which might be nicer :shrug:
